messages.content:
You are an expert software engineer specialized in bug localization. 
Your task is to identify the files most likely to contain bugs based on bug descriptions. 
You have access to several tools to help you in this task. 
From the files you have seen, you will select 1 files that you believe are most likely to contain the bug.

Accessing UserAdmin via to_field leads to link to PasswordResetForm being broken (404) Description (last modified by Simon Kern) Accessing the UserAdmin via another model's Admin that has a reference to User (with to_field set, e.g., to_field="uuid") leads to the UserAdmin being accessed via an url that looks similar to this one: .../user/22222222-3333-4444-5555-666677778888/change/?_to_field=uuid However the underlying form looks like this: Code highlighting: class UserChangeForm(forms.ModelForm): password = ReadOnlyPasswordHashField( label=_("Password"), help_text=_( "Raw passwords are not stored, so there is no way to see this " "user’s password, but you can change the password using " 'this form.' ), ) ... ... def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super().__init__(*args, **kwargs) password = self.fields.get("password") if password: password.help_text = password.help_text.format("../password/") ... ... This results in the link to the PasswordResetForm being wrong and thus ending up in a 404. If we drop the assumption that UserAdmin is always accessed via its pk, then we're good to go. It's as simple as replacing password.help_text = password.help_text.format("../password/") with password.help_text = password.help_text.format(f"../../{self.instance.pk}/password/") I've opened a pull request on GitHub for this Ticket, please see: ​PR The repository name is: django__django__d559cb02da30f74debbb1fc3a46de0df134d2d80 You have access to the following tools: * extract_relevant() -> Retrieve the most relevant info from the bug. Returns a JSON object with explanation, relevant code snippets, error messages and file paths mentioned in the bug. * You must use these tools to find 1 files that are most likely to contain the bug. Start by analyzing the issue description and then decide which tool to use first. If you are done, provide your final ranked list of 1 files most likely to contain bugs in a JSON array as follows: {"ranked_files": ["file1", "file2", ...]} Otherwise, return only the tool call as JSON. Example: {"function_call": "func_name", "args": {"arg_name": 10} } Reply ONLY with the JSON response.

query_preview: The bug occurs when accessing UserAdmin via another model's Admin with to_field set. The password reset link in UserChangeForm is constructed incorrectly, leading to a 404 error. The link uses '../password/' instead of the correct '../../{user_id}/password/' path. user_admin.py UserChangeForm password help_text 404 error when accessing PasswordResetForm link class UserChangeForm(forms.ModelForm): password = ReadOnlyPasswordHashField( label=_("Password"), help_text=_( "Raw passwords are not stored, so there is no way to see this " "user’s password, but you can change the password using " 'this form." ), ) ... def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super().__init__(*args, **kwargs) password = self.fields.get("password") if password: password.help_text = password.help_text.format("../password/")

You are an expert software engineer specialized in bug localization. 
Your task is to identify the files most likely to contain bugs based on bug descriptions. 
You have access to several tools to help you in this task. 
From the files you have seen, you will select 1 files that you believe are most likely to contain the bug.

Accessing UserAdmin via to_field leads to link to PasswordResetForm being broken (404) Description (last modified by Simon Kern) Accessing the UserAdmin via another model's Admin that has a reference to User (with to_field set, e.g., to_field="uuid") leads to the UserAdmin being accessed via an url that looks similar to this one: .../user/22222222-3333-4444-5555-666677778888/change/?_to_field=uuid However the underlying form looks like this: Code highlighting: class UserChangeForm(forms.ModelForm): password = ReadOnlyPasswordHashField( label=_("Password"), help_text=_( "Raw passwords are not stored, so there is no way to see this " "user’s password, but you can change the password using " 'this form.' ), ) ... ... def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super().__init__(*args, **kwargs) password = self.fields.get("password") if password: password.help_text = password.help_text.format("../password/") ... ... This results in the link to the PasswordResetForm being wrong and thus ending up in a 404. If we drop the assumption that UserAdmin is always accessed via its pk, then we're good to go. It's as simple as replacing password.help_text = password.help_text.format("../password/") with password.help_text = password.help_text.format(f"../../{self.instance.pk}/password/") I've opened a pull request on GitHub for this Ticket, please see: ​PR The repository name is: django__django__d559cb02da30f74debbb1fc3a46de0df134d2d80 You have access to the following tools: * extract_relevant() -> Retrieve the most relevant info from the bug. Returns a JSON object with explanation, relevant code snippets, error messages and file paths mentioned in the bug. * You must use these tools to find 1 files that are most likely to contain the bug. Start by analyzing the issue description and then decide which tool to use first. If you are done, provide your final ranked list of 1 files most likely to contain bugs in a JSON array as follows: {"ranked_files": ["file1", "file2", ...]} Otherwise, return only the tool call as JSON. Example: {"function_call": "func_name", "args": {"arg_name": 10} } Reply ONLY with the JSON response.

Based on the tool call results, please select your next action. Recall that you need to provide the 1 files most likely to contain bugs.

This is the bug description: Accessing UserAdmin via to_field leads to link to PasswordResetForm being broken (404) Description (last modified by Simon Kern) Accessing the UserAdmin via another model's Admin that has a reference to User (with to_field set, e.g., to_field="uuid") leads to the UserAdmin being accessed via an url that looks similar to this one: .../user/22222222-3333-4444-5555-666677778888/change/?_to_field=uuid However the underlying form looks like this: Code highlighting: class UserChangeForm(forms.ModelForm): password = ReadOnlyPasswordHashField( label=_("Password"), help_text=_( "Raw passwords are not stored, so there is no way to see this " "user’s password, but you can change the password using " 'this form.' ), ) ... ... def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super().__init__(*args, **kwargs) password = self.fields.get("password") if password: password.help_text = password.help_text.format("../password/") ... ... This results in the link to the PasswordResetForm being wrong and thus ending up in a 404. If we drop the assumption that UserAdmin is always accessed via its pk, then we're good to go. It's as simple as replacing password.help_text = password.help_text.format("../password/") with password.help_text = password.help_text.format(f"../../{self.instance.pk}/password/") I've opened a pull request on GitHub for this Ticket, please see: ​PR BM25 retrieved the following files: { "files": [ "django/contrib/auth/forms.py", "django/contrib/auth/admin.py", "django/contrib/auth/views.py", "django/contrib/auth/models.py", "django/contrib/auth/hashers.py", "django/contrib/auth/password_validation.py", "django/contrib/auth/base_user.py", "django/contrib/auth/management/commands/createsuperuser.py", "django/db/backends/oracle/creation.py", "django/contrib/admin/sites.py", "django/contrib/auth/__init__.py", "django/contrib/auth/tokens.py", "django/contrib/auth/backends.py", "django/views/decorators/debug.py", "django/db/backends/mysql/base.py", "django/db/backends/postgresql/base.py", "django/conf/global_settings.py", "django/db/backends/mysql/client.py", "django/contrib/auth/management/commands/changepassword.py", "django/contrib/admin/utils.py" ] } You have also viewed the following files during your investigation: ["django/contrib/auth/forms.py", "django/contrib/auth/forms.py", "django/contrib/auth/admin.py", "django/contrib/auth/forms.py", "django/contrib/auth/forms.py", "django/contrib/auth/forms.py"] This is the final ranked list of files you provided: ["django/contrib/auth/forms.py"].
